title: Addressing the issue of inactive credit cards
projectName: Addressing the issue of inactive credit cards
problemStatement:
A significant proportion of newly issued credit cards
                      remain inactive within the first 30 days, leading to
                      revenue leakage and underutilized acquisition investments.
                      Activating these customers through personalized,
                      AI/ML-driven nudges can unlock immediate transaction
                      revenue and improve long-term engagement.
Recommendation Systems / Personalization

                      prioritization framework• Personalized activation journeys with tailored offers

                      full-scale implementation

title: AI-Driven Financial Literacy and Nudging for MSMEs
projectName: AI-Driven Financial Literacy and Nudging for MSMEs
problemStatement: There is a need to improve financial literacy among MSMEs. Only 36% of adults in Malaysia meet basic financial literacy standards, and many SME owners face challenges in interpreting cash flow statements or creating bankable documents.
Generative AI (text, image, video, code generation), Recommendation Systems / Personalization, Conversational AI / Chatbots
• MSMEs Financial Builder: An AI tool to nudge MSMEs to submit information or take actions to improve their "trust profile".
• Live Adaptive Learning: Interactive, scenario-based workshops and educational content that adapts to user maturity and recommends relevant products.
• Gamification Engine: A gamified app experience to nudge behavior, allowing high-level users to access preferential rates or exclusive financing.

Education for MSMEs is currently delivered through broad-base content creation that does not cater to the specific stages of different MSMEs. Content is typically distributed via social media, websites, or banking staff.
The SME Banking Team, by enriching their content offerings to potential clients and improving product adoption.
The bank possesses a large amount of structured content on its website and other platforms, as well as unstructured content in video formats, flyers, pamphlets, and product disclosure forms.

The solution should be on-premise, with the bank owning the IP. The company is open to a white-labeling or SaaS model. The MVP's focus is on the viability of the engine rather than the content itself.
XXX

title: AI-Driven Financial Literacy and Nudging for MSMEs
projectName: AI-Driven Financial Literacy and Nudging for MSMEs
problemStatement: There is a need to improve financial literacy among MSMEs. Only 36% of adults in Malaysia meet basic financial literacy standards, and many SME owners face challenges in interpreting cash flow statements or creating bankable documents.
Generative AI (text, image, video, code generation), Recommendation Systems / Personalization, Conversational AI / Chatbots
• MSMEs Financial Builder: An AI tool to nudge MSMEs to submit information or take actions to improve their "trust profile".
• Live Adaptive Learning: Interactive, scenario-based workshops and educational content that adapts to user maturity and recommends relevant products.
• Gamification Engine: A gamified app experience to nudge behavior, allowing high-level users to access preferential rates or exclusive financing.

Education for MSMEs is currently delivered through broad-base content creation that does not cater to the specific stages of different MSMEs. Content is typically distributed via social media, websites, or banking staff.
The SME Banking Team, by enriching their content offerings to potential clients and improving product adoption.
The bank possesses a large amount of structured content on its website and other platforms, as well as unstructured content in video formats, flyers, pamphlets, and product disclosure forms.

The solution should be on-premise, with the bank owning the IP. The company is open to a white-labeling or SaaS model. The MVP's focus is on the viability of the engine rather than the content itself.
XXX

title: AI-Powered MSME Onboarding and Credit Profiling
projectName: AI-Powered MSME Onboarding and Credit Profiling
problemStatement: The onboarding process for Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs) into the banking industry is highly manual, requiring days to complete due to extensive documentation. Additionally, many MSMEs operate in a personal capacity, which restricts their access to business-specific financial tools that could foster growth.
Document Intelligence (data extraction from PDFs, forms, contracts), Predictive Analytics / Forecasting, Generative AI (text, image, video, code generation)
• Achieve seamless and digital onboarding for MSMEs with near real-time approvals using eKYB and document recognition.
• Develop a transactional behavior engine for credit profiling and segmentation based on non-traditional data like e-wallet usage, QR payments, and e-commerce sales.
No specific tools or vendors. Onboarding of MSME clients is a manual process , and qualification of potential clients is done through manual data analytics.
The SME Banking Team, by expanding the funnel for potential MSME leads and clients.
Transactional data is available in a structured format. However, historical onboarding documents are in an unstructured format.
The desired solution should be deployed on-premise, with the intellectual property ultimately belonging to the bank. The company is looking for a white-labeling or a SaaS model of engagement.
XXX

title: AI-Powered CNS Drug Discovery Platform
problemStatement: NeuroLeap–PanAsia Hub was founded to address urgent challenges in central nervous system (CNS) drug development, especially in Asia, with the following key points:

• Rising disease burden in Asia: Stroke, Parkinson’s disease (PD) are becoming urgent public-health challenges, surpassing cancer. The economic impact is equally stark: stroke alone consumed US $330 billion in direct health-care outlays in 2019, most of it borne by Asian nations.

• High failure rates and long development times: Only 6–8 % of CNS drug candidates reach the market, and the approval timeline lasts 10-15 years, and the early compound-optimisation (hit-to-lead) stage takes 6–9 months.
• High cost to invest a CNS drug: Each approved CNS drug can cost USD 2–4 billion, and budgets for IND submissions in the US are USD 5-10 million.
If no region-specific R&D solutions are implemented, CNS treatment costs will surpass cancer spending before 2035.

Why Now: AI is unlocking a new era of faster, cheaper drug discovery. Breakthroughs from players like Insilico Medicine and Google DeepMind (AlphaFold) have proven that AI can cut years off timelines and reduce costs dramatically. Leveraging this same AI advantage, NeuroLeap-PanAsia Hub focuses on CNS disorders, especially PD and stroke, two diseases that significantly affect the Asia economy.
Predictive Analytics / Forecasting, Generative AI (text, image, video, code generation), Search & Knowledge Retrieval

By combining in silico, in vitro, and in vivo workflows in cost-efficient, government-supported labs in Southeast Asia, the NeuroLeap-PanAsia Hub aims to deliver CNS drug candidates up to 5× faster and at 1/5th the cost of traditional pipelines.
(1) Accelerate drug development:
• Shorten the hit-to-lead cycle to ≤ 30 days (a 6–9× speed-up vs. the industry average) by Month 18.
• Potentially compress the path to an IND-ready candidate from years to just months.
• Deliver CNS drug candidates 5× faster.
• Nominate at least one IND-ready CNS candidate by Month 36.
(2) Reduce R&D costs:
• Cut hit-to-lead optimization costs to ≤ USD 0.5 million per lead (a ≥75–90% saving vs. the typical USD 3–5 million).
• Develop drugs at one-fifth the cost of traditional processes.
• Save ~USD 1.2 million vs. market averages by retrofitting the lab and using open-source compute resources.
(3) Economic and societal impact:
• Cut CNS drug‐discovery costs by up to ~USD 40-100 million across Asia through faster hit-to-lead cycles and MaaS licensing.
• Democratize precision neurology, reduce treatment disparities, and strengthen Asia’s health-data sovereignty.
The NeuroLeap–PanAsia Hub is supported by a four-member consortium, each contributing critical capabilities to close gaps in Asia-focused CNS drug discovery:
(1) Genetica (Vietnam) — Wet-Lab Construction & Operations
• Provides CLIA-certified laboratory infrastructure with robotic 384‑ and 1 536‑well screening capabilities.
• Responsible for high-throughput assay development, validation, and execution to feed in vitro data into the AI engine.
(2) Hanoi Medical University (Vietnam) — Clinical Cohorts & Preclinical Efficacy
• Supplies richly phenotyped patient populations for federated data federation (stroke, PD, ADRD).
• Conducts GLP-compliant in vivo efficacy studies and supports IND gap analyses under its GCP-accredited Phase I unit.
(3) LIFE AI Pte Ltd (Singapore) — AI Models & Data Infrastructure
• Provides the core multi‑agent AI stack and leads the consortium, bringing DevSecOps muscle honed on > 100 k daily active health‑app users.
• Manages data harmonization, model training, and continuous MLOps to support predictive workflows across the pipeline.
(4) Kalbe Farma Tbk (Indonesia) — Pharma Development & Commercial Scale‑Up
• Provides GMP/GLP facilities for CMC studies, stability testing, and scale-up manufacturing of lead candidates.
• Leverages ASEAN regulatory affairs expertise and distribution network to prepare IND dossiers and plan regional market entry
(1) AI Platform → MaaS
NeuroLeap’s AI engine is offered as “Model-as-a-Service” (MaaS), delivering real-time, multi-agent CNS drug-discovery workflows via API or web portal.
(2) Monetization Model:
• Buyers: Pharmaceutical and biotech companies, as well as contract research organizations (CROs), subscribe to monthly or usage-based credits to access our inference and optimization services.

• Payers: R&D and innovation budgets within those organizations cover subscription fees, approved by senior leadership against projected ROI from accelerated hit-to-lead timelines and reduced late-stage failures.
(3) Target Audiences:

• Lead Discovery Teams: Medicinal chemists and assay biologists who need rapid, data-driven iteration. -> The 30-day hit-to-lead cycle directly accelerates their design–test–iterate loops, enabling them to screen larger libraries at lower cost (USD 11.20 per assay capacity) and de-risk candidate selection earlier.

• Preclinical & CMC Units: In vivo pharmacology groups and process chemists seeking integrated AI feedback to streamline formulation and toxicity testing. ->  Integrated data feedback from AI recommendations reduces redundant experiments, compresses CMC lead-optimization timelines, and ensures that every mouse study or formulation run (at ~USD 0.7 M per lead) directly informs IND-ready outputs.

• Clinical Strategy & Regulatory Affairs: Trial design and IND-filing experts leveraging curated real-world evidence to de-risk protocols. -> AI-curated RWE accelerates clinical-trial design, minimizes protocol amendments, and streamlines IND preparation, ensuring nomination of at least one IND-ready candidate by Month 36.

• Innovation & Venture Committees: Corporate innovation offices and biotech investors evaluating high-ROI platforms to expedite CNS pipelines. -> The blended grant + SaaS revenue model and clear break-even by Year 4 (with up to USD 4 M/year from mature MaaS and milestone fees) provide predictable financials and de-risked innovation pathways—making NeuroLeap a compelling strategic lever for portfolio acceleration
To power NeuroLeap’s AI-driven CNS-discovery workflows, we require and already possess a comprehensive, multi-modal dataset spanning >10 years:
(1) Genomic & Clinical Data

• What & Format: >150 000 whole-genome sequences (GP2) and HMU’s de-identified electronic health records (EHR), including diagnosis codes, laboratory values, and longitudinal patient outcomes. These reside in relational databases/CSV exports, ready for ingestion.
• Readiness: Data lake v1 is live (M4) and populated with these structured tables .
(2) High-Throughput Assay Records

• What & Format: 12 years of plate-reader and robotic-assay outputs (384- and 1 536-well formats), including plate maps, Z′ scores, and dose–response curves—captured as structured CSVs with API hooks into the CLIA-certified LIMS.
• Readiness: 12 prototype assays run in Phase 1 (M6–M18) achieved Z′ > 0.5 across >70% of plates .
(3) Literature & Registry Feeds
• What & Format: Unstructured PDFs and XML from PubMed, clinical-trial registries (including Asian cohorts), and curated omics studies—fed into a federated knowledge graph.
• Readiness: Ontologies and NLP pipelines have already processed >5 million abstracts and trial entries, merging them with structured omics endpoints .
(4) Proof-of-Concept (POC)

• 10-Year Track Record: Our Insilico Medicine POC (ISM-001) advanced from target nomination to first-in-human dosing in 30 months, demonstrating the platform’s ability to handle long-tail, real-world R&D data and deliver actionable leads .

We already control both structured (CSV/DB) and unstructured (PDF, registry feeds) datasets spanning 10 years, plus a validated POC, confirming that NeuroLeap’s data foundation is production-ready to meet all AI and regulatory requirements.
NeuroLeap-PanAsia Hub integrates four synergistic “gears,” each mapped directly to our key performance targets (≤ 30-day hit-to-lead, 5× faster candidate delivery, IND nomination by Month 36):
(1) AI Engine

• Technology & Outcome: NVIDIA-GPU clusters running multi-agent generative AI, enriched with the latest CNS literature and proprietary deep-learning models, continuously ingest wet-lab and in vivo data to recommend next-best actions.
• Alignment: Real-time inference drives our ≤ 30-day hit-to-lead cycle and supports go/no-go decisions within days, not months.
(2) High-Throughput Wet-Lab (Genetica, Vietnam)
• Technology & Outcome: CLIA-certified, robotic 1,536-well assays deliver fresh biological readouts every 24 hours.
• Alignment: Rapid data generation feeds the AI Engine without delay—compressing early optimization into a single month and accelerating lead selection.
(3) In Vivo & CMC Network (HMU & Kalbe Farma)
• Technology & Outcome: GCP-accredited preclinical studies at HMU (e.g., mouse models for BBB penetration, PK/PD, toxicity) and seamless CMC workflows via Kalbe Farma’s GMP/GLP facilities.
• Alignment: Integrated data loops ensure that late-stage optimization and manufacturing inputs are handled in parallel, cutting our path to an IND-ready candidate from years to just months.
(4) Clinical-Design & IND Preparation (HMU)
• Technology & Outcome: Expert clinical-trial design informed by AI-curated datasets, plus end-to-end IND dossier assembly leveraging HMU’s FDA-approved CNS-trial experience.
• Alignment: Ensures at least one IND-ready CNS candidate nomination by Month 36, with regulatory documentation optimized via AI.

Together, these four pillars drive a candidate seamlessly from a 1,536-well screening plate → AI-guided optimization → rodent validation → GMP production → IND filing, meeting our targets for speed, cost efficiency, and milestone delivery.

Targeted Milestones:
• Month 0–3: Project kickoff, infrastructure setup, and data-ingestion pipelines live.
• Month 4–12: Upgrade Genetica CLIA lab (≤30-day hit-to-lead); achieve ≥ 5 000 compounds/week.
• Month 13–24: Deploy AI Engine on H100 cluster; hit AUROC ≥ 0.80 and scale to ≥ 10 000 compounds/week.
• Month 25–30: Stand up federated-learning network; onboard ≥ 10 000 patient records with zero raw-data export.
• Month 31–34: Nominate first brain-penetrant lead and deliver full IND-gap analysis.
• Month 35–36: Finalize IND dossier and nominate ≥ 1 IND-ready CNS candidate.
In summary: NeuroLeap delivers drug-discovery at ~5× lower cost and ~5× higher speed versus traditional pipelines.

(1) Accelerate drug development:
• Shorten the hit-to-lead cycle to ≤ 30 days (a 6–9× speed-up vs. the industry average) by Month 18.
• Potentially compress the path to an IND-ready candidate from years to just months.
• Deliver CNS drug candidates 5× faster.
• Nominate at least one IND-ready CNS candidate by Month 36.
(2) Reduce R&D costs:
• Cut hit-to-lead optimization costs to ≤ USD 0.5 million per lead (a ≥75–90% saving vs. the typical USD 3–5 million).
• Develop drugs at one-fifth the cost of traditional processes.

The NeuroLeap–PanAsia Hub is supported by a four-member consortium, each contributing critical capabilities to close gaps in Asia-focused CNS drug discovery:
(1) Genetica (Vietnam) — Wet-Lab Construction & Operations

• Supplies richly phenotyped patient populations for federated data federation (stroke, PD, ADRD).
• Conducts GLP-compliant in vivo efficacy studies and supports IND gap analyses under its GCP-accredited Phase I unit.
(3) LIFE AI Pte Ltd (Singapore) — AI Models & Data Infrastructure
• Provides the core multi‑agent AI stack and leads the consortium, bringing DevSecOps muscle honed on > 100 k daily active health‑app users.

(1) AI Platform → MaaS
NeuroLeap’s AI engine is offered as “Model-as-a-Service” (MaaS), delivering real-time, multi-agent CNS drug-discovery workflows via API or web portal.
(2) Monetization Model:
• Buyers: Pharmaceutical and biotech companies, as well as contract research organizations (CROs), subscribe to monthly or usage-based credits to access our inference and optimization services.

• Payers: R&D and innovation budgets within those organizations cover subscription fees, approved by senior leadership against projected ROI from accelerated hit-to-lead timelines and reduced late-stage failures.
(3) Target Audiences:

• Lead Discovery Teams: Medicinal chemists and assay biologists who need rapid, data-driven iteration. -> The 30-day hit-to-lead cycle directly accelerates their design–test–iterate loops, enabling them to screen larger libraries at lower cost (USD 11.20 per assay capacity) and de-risk candidate selection earlier.

• Preclinical & CMC Units: In vivo pharmacology groups and process chemists seeking integrated AI feedback to streamline formulation and toxicity testing. ->  Integrated data feedback from AI recommendations reduces redundant experiments, compresses CMC lead-optimization timelines, and ensures that every mouse study or formulation run (at ~USD 0.7 M per lead) directly informs IND-ready outputs.

• Clinical Strategy & Regulatory Affairs: Trial design and IND-filing experts leveraging curated real-world evidence to de-risk protocols. -> AI-curated RWE accelerates clinical-trial design, minimizes protocol amendments, and streamlines IND preparation, ensuring nomination of at least one IND-ready candidate by Month 36.

• Innovation & Venture Committees: Corporate innovation offices and biotech investors evaluating high-ROI platforms to expedite CNS pipelines. -> The blended grant + SaaS revenue model and clear break-even by Year 4 (with up to USD 4 M/year from mature MaaS and milestone fees) provide predictable financials and de-risked innovation pathways—making NeuroLeap a compelling strategic lever for portfolio acceleration

In summary: NeuroLeap delivers drug-discovery at ~5× lower cost and ~5× higher speed versus traditional pipelines.

title: AI-Powered Content Adaptation and Localization
problemStatement: Content development across our brands is highly siloed — only specific individuals can write or translate for specific brands or languages because of the unique tone, style, and editorial voice. This leads to bottlenecks and underutilised resources. We lack a scalable system that allows team members from one brand/language group to create or adapt content for another while maintaining the brand’s identity and tone.
Generative AI (text, image, video, code generation), Search & Knowledge Retrieval
• Reduce content localization turnaround time by 70%.
• Achieve 90%+ consistency with brand tone.
• Increase regional content output by 2–3x without growing team size.

Currently using a mix of manual translation and generic AI tools, which lack brand context and require heavy editorial post-editing. Some early tests with internal summarization and translation models have shown promise.
Editorial teams, content producers, social media teams, and branded/commercial content teams across Media Prima.

• Must align with our internal content governance and data privacy policies
• Regional language support and GPU access preferred

projectName: AI-Powered MSME Onboarding and Credit Profiling
problemStatement: The onboarding process for Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs) into the banking industry is highly manual, requiring days to complete due to extensive documentation. Additionally, many MSMEs operate in a personal capacity, which restricts their access to business-specific financial tools that could foster growth.
Document Intelligence (data extraction from PDFs, forms, contracts), Predictive Analytics / Forecasting, Generative AI (text, image, video, code generation)
• Achieve seamless and digital onboarding for MSMEs with near real-time approvals using eKYB and document recognition.
• Develop a transactional behavior engine for credit profiling and segmentation based on non-traditional data like e-wallet usage, QR payments, and e-commerce sales.
No specific tools or vendors. Onboarding of MSME clients is a manual process , and qualification of potential clients is done through manual data analytics.
The SME Banking Team, by expanding the funnel for potential MSME leads and clients.
Transactional data is available in a structured format. However, historical onboarding documents are in an unstructured format.
The desired solution should be deployed on-premise, with the intellectual property ultimately belonging to the bank. The company is looking for a white-labeling or a SaaS model of engagement.

title: API-Controlled Virtual Host for Hybrid Environments
projectName: API-Controlled Virtual Host for Hybrid Environments
problemStatement: Deploy a virtual host/avatar that can be controlled on-demand via API calls. No existing integrated solution meets the requirements for human-like avatars, multilingual voice, real-time control, and hybrid deployment. This includes customized hand gestures controllable on demand.
Generative AI (text, image, video, code generation), Voice AI (speech recognition, voice bots), Computer Vision (image/video recognition, OCR)
• Support 1,000+ concurrent users with <1-second latency for command processing and scene transitions.
• Deliver high-resolution (1080p) graphics with human-like virtual host avatars and smooth animations.
• Provide at least 95% accurate responses from API calls or instructions.
• Achieve 95% accurate multilingual voice-over delivery, supporting at least Traditional Chinese, Simplified Chinese, and English.
• Maintain 99.9% uptime for cloud-based or on-premise deployments.
• Ensure secure handling of command inputs and data exchanges to prevent unauthorized access.
• Provide API readiness for integration with external systems.
• Operate in hybrid deployment environments (AWS cloud or on-premise physical servers, with limited or no internet access).

There are no currently used solutions. The Virtual Host System will be a new implementation to address identified requirements for human-like avatars, complex object interactions, real-time multilingual voice, and seamless API integration within hybrid deployment environments. Many do not support real-time API-driven control, multilingual voice-over with high accuracy, or hybrid deployment across both cloud and offline on-premise environments. Current tools also lack the <1-second latency and 1,000+ concurrent user performance required for large-scale deployments.
• Event Management Teams – for large-scale virtual conferences and live events.
• Customer Service Teams – for interactive virtual reception and guided assistance.
• Training & Education Teams – for immersive, scenario-based learning simulations.
• Entertainment & Gaming Teams – for interactive storylines and virtual experiences.

• Input Data: Command sets (text, voice, UI), scene definitions, object libraries, integration endpoints, and a set of predefined scripts/data/ hand gestures tailored to specific scenarios (e.g., customer service, event hosting, or virtual assistant interactions).
• Scripts: Include triggers (keywords, phrases, or intents) and corresponding responses.
• Formats: API endpoints, multimedia assets (MP4 video, RTSP live stream), and multilingual voice assets.
• Readiness: Scene libraries, object interaction definitions, and command protocols are defined. Voice-over assets for required languages are part of the initial deployment scope.
• Integration: API-ready for external platforms (event management systems, VR/AR tools, or service platforms).
• Deployment: Supports hybrid models – AWS cloud hosting or on-premise servers with limited/no internet access.
• Infrastructure: Capable of running on GPU-enabled AWS instances or physical servers.
• Output: MP4 for recorded video delivery, RTSP for live streaming to end users or integrated platforms.
• Security: Encrypted communication for all command inputs and data exchanges to prevent unauthorized access.
Entertainment, Hospitality, Virtual Events, Digital Human, Generative AI, Voice AI

                      representatives, with 80% of them outsourced to a
                      third-party vendor. We utilized a contact center provided
                      by a local telecommunications provider. However, due to
                      the high volume of cases, we encountered significant
                      challenges. The high turnover rate among service agents,
                      coupled with an unsatisfactory NPS score, and an extended
                      turnaround time from hours to days, hindered our ability
                      to meet customer expectations. Anticipating continued
                      customer growth, we estimated that we would need to double
                      the number of agents within the same year to meet demand.
                      This would necessitate an extension of the contact
                      center's license and subscription.

Customer Service division for both Retail and Liobank

title: Casino Floor and Pricing Optimization via Natural Language Analytics
projectName: Casino Floor and Pricing Optimization via Natural Language Analytics
problemStatement: • Difficult in searching and retrieving meaningful business insight and performance analytics in casino environment. Users need the ability to generate insights using natural language.

• Inability to determine optimal product and pricing strategies. Currently, rely on try-and-error by manually setting different price points or product offering to evaluate its performance. Pricing means machine minimum bet amount, table game minimum bet amount. Product offering refers to optimum number of gaming table, slot and electronic table games, and the product type.
• Floor optimization – difficult determining the ideal placement of slot machine type to maximize revenue
Search & Knowledge Retrieval, Predictive Analytics / Forecasting, Recommendation Systems / Personalization
• Use natural language to generate instant business insights.
• Provide product and pricing recommendations with revenue predictions.
• Provide slot machine placement recommendations, e.g. popular machines at low-traffic areas to drive traffic.
• Manually filter and retrieve info from BI platform, or export reports and further process the data in Excel.
• Experiment with different pricing, product offerings, and table/machine placement and monitor the result. This requires months of monitoring and repeated reconfiguration cycles.
The Casino Operation team.

• We have operational database with detail slot machine, gaming table and player transaction data, which includes length of play, time of play, total wager, winning, bill drop, average bet, machine info such as machine name, type, location, denomination/min bet (pricing), volatility (risk level), machine return percentage, etc.
• In summary, a wide range and comprehensive data is available.
• Integration: possibly extract data from operation database
• Deployment: on-premise preferred, but cloud solution can be explored too.
• Infra: No specific requirements.
• Compliance: standard IT security compliance requirements, e.g. protect the data from unauthorize access, etc.

title: Certificate of Analysis Automation
problemStatement: We receive Ceritificate of Analysis (COA) on a daily basis for all raw materials we receive from suppliers both locally and internationally. These COAs comes in various formats, benchmark results criteria and layout - they're vital in quality assurance process to ensure raw materials meet international standards and internal control criteria before acceptance is performed.

Currently, these documents are either received via email or physical copies and are analysed by QA team manually to detect out of specifications and anomalies for quality rejection process. This is painstakingly difficult due to the vast amount of lab COA formats and benchmark results for a large portoflio of raw materials from commodities like flour to small batches of flavouring additives.

Generative AI (text, image, video, code generation), Predictive Analytics / Forecasting, Document Intelligence (data extraction from PDFs, forms, contracts), Computer Vision (image/video recognition, OCR)

Fully automate incoming COA reading via OCR with AI capabilities to detect anomaly by learning benchmark results of each raw material groups or test results category. With these data, to also predict non-conformace rate or performance of a supplier based on historical trend and propose next steps for QA team to act on. Example: if Supplier A always fails on Microbes test, to automatically focus on this test result for next incoming COA.
Currently entire workflow is done manually without any system in place. SAP comes at the tail end for usage decision and stock release only.
Quality assurance team, incoming warehouse receiving team, R&D team
Unstructured COAs in PDFs, emails, and hardcopies occasionally for imported raw materials.
TBD (To Be Determined)
PoC by end of Q4 2025

title: Gen-AI Bank Coach Companion for MSMEs
projectName: Gen-AI Bank Coach Companion for MSMEs
problemStatement: MSMEs currently have difficulty getting answers to financial service and bank-specific queries, as the current support systems are not scalable.
Generative AI (text, image, video, code generation), Conversational AI / Chatbots, Search & Knowledge Retrieval
To create a "Bank Coach Companion," a Generative-AI platform that enables MSMEs to interact with the bank's grounded knowledge base to get answers to FAQs and receive guidance on becoming SME-ready.
All queries are currently handled by the customer service line, bank branch staff, or relationship managers, which is not scalable and carries a risk of mis-selling.
SME Banking, Branch Staff, and Relationship Managers.
The knowledge base is mainly unstructured, with most information located on printed forms or websites.
The solution must be deployed on-premise. The Gen-AI must be grounded, sourcing knowledge only from the bank's approved information to ensure accuracy and compliance.

title: GenAI for 2D-to-3D Asset Generation
problemStatement:
Campaigns increasingly demand dynamic and immersive visuals, but producing 3D assets from scratch remains expensive and time-consuming. Teams struggle to scale 3D asset creation across product types, scenes, and motion use cases.
Current 2D-to-3D tools have limited control, poor background variation, and often lack the capability to generate cinematic motion or video content. There’s a need for generative models (e.g., diffusion models) that can automate and scale 3D generation with creative flexibility.
Generative AI (text, image, video, code generation), Conversational AI / Chatbots, Other: Diffusion Models (Text/2D to 3D scene), NeRF

•	Convert existing 2D visuals into high-quality 3D static images and motion clips
•	Enable rapid prototyping of product shots, scenes, and campaign ideas
•	Reduce 3D production time and cost by 50–80%
•	Improve creative freedom and customization of 3D backgrounds and visual environments
•	Support downstream usage in AR/VR, e-commerce, and digital campaign assets

•	Manual 3D modeling and rendering workflows
•	No scalable or automated pipeline for 2D-to-3D transformation
•	Limited 3D motion output or integration into brand campaigns

•	Visual Design & Motion Teams – for rendering and asset creation
•	Campaign & Brand Teams – to experiment with formats and storytelling
•	Innovation & Tech Creative Teams – to prototype immersive experiences

•	Product imagery and packaging shots available in high resolution
•	Creative guidelines and scene composition templates exist
•	Lack of clean 3D object datasets or 3D-aware prompt libraries
•	No unified metadata tagging system for asset recall and reuse
•	Preferred to integrate with:
Prototype Start: September 2025 (1–2 product categories, 2D-to-motion). Pilot Scope: Oct–Dec 2025, across seasonal campaign visuals

title: Integrated Store Communication & Compliance Checklist — Digitised Store Ops & Compliance
projectName: Integrated Store Communication & Compliance Checklist — Digitised Store Ops & Compliance
problemStatement: Other: NLP for checklist ingestion and automated classification/routing.   Conversational UI and guided mobile workflows for store teams.   Computer vision for photo-based evidence validation (e.g., hygiene or display issues).   Predictive analytics to identify stores at risk of failing audits or where compliance correlates with lower sales.   Anomaly detection for unusual checklist patterns or recurring issues.

Secure, HQ-controlled communication (replaces WhatsApp)
Target: Pilot ≥ 80% ops/escalations handled in the platform (not WhatsApp), 100% staff sign in with company email/SSO, leavers removed ≤ 24h, 0 non-employee members →  Scale ≥ 95% in-platform, resigned staff removed ≤ 4h, 0 non-employee members.

On-time work with proper evidence
Target: Pilot ≥ 95% tasks done on time & ≥ 90% cases with photo, time, and location → Scale ≥ 98%

Fast handling and closure of issues
Target: Pilot ≥ 90% issues assigned ≤ 15 min & ≥ 85% closed within agreed time: time to fix −35% → Scale ≥ 95% assigned ≤ 10 min & ≥ 95% within agreed time; time to fix −60%.

Clear link to sales and fewer sales disruptions
Target: Pilot compliance-to-sales dashboard live by Week 2 & days of sales affected by critical issues −40% → Scale 100% stores linked (weekly refresh) & −70%.

Better fixes, fewer repeats
Target: Pilot first-time fix ≥ 75% & repeat issues −30% → Scale first-time fix ≥ 85% & −50%.

Store issues are reported via WhatsApp, paper forms, and spreadsheets, leading to uncontrolled access, message loss, and poor traceability. Ownership is often unclear, with no standardized follow-up to ensure timely closure. Evidence (photos, timestamps, locations) is inconsistently captured and not reliably linked to cases. Management lacks a consolidated, real-time view across stores, and fragmented data cannot be correlated with sales, food safety audit (SQC) or customer experience. The result is slow resolution, elevated store SQC risk, and the absence of a single, controlled, auditable process to capture, assign, track, and close issues.

Store teams & shift managers (primary users)
QA / Food safety auditors
Operations & regional managers (dashboards & escalations)
Customer experience / CRM & sales teams (performance correlation)
Maintenance & facilities teams (task assignment)

title: Streamlining Withholding Tax (WHT) Processing for Corporate Card Expenses
projectName: Streamlining Withholding Tax (WHT) Processing for Corporate Card Expenses
problemStatement: The current process of managing WHT for corporate card expenses is highly manual and inefficient. With around 100 small-value transactions monthly, the team faces significant workload in document compilation, WHT computation, invoice creation, and payment processing. This leads to delays, high resource use, and risk of errors.

Computer Vision (image/video recognition, OCR), Robotic Process Automation (RPA), Anomaly Detection / Fraud Detection, Recommendation Systems / Personalization, Document Intelligence (data extraction from PDFs, forms, contracts), Other: Workflow automation & AI-powered approval routing , Machine Learning for tax computation and anomaly detection

Automated document extraction and verification
Bulk or auto-calculated WHT for recurring small-value transactions
Auto-generation of invoices and system entries
Streamlined approval workflow for batch payments
50–70% reduction in processing time and manual effort
Manual handling: transactions processed individually, invoices keyed in one by one, WHT computed manually, payments submitted for approval case-by-case.

Finance team (accounts payable, tax compliance)
Employees using corporate cards
Internal approvers for payments

Historical transaction data available in finance system
Supporting documents (receipts, invoices) available digitally (PDF/scanned)
Basic WHT computation rules already in use

Integration with existing finance/ERP systems (Oracle)
Cloud-based AI service with API compatibility
Secure handling of financial and tax data (compliance ready)
TBD (To Be Determined)

title: Supplier Collaboration Hub
problemStatement: Collaboration between the company and material suppliers is still largely manual and fragmented across multiple channels (email, WhatsApp, spreadsheets, Microsoft Teams). This fragmentation limits visibility of stock availability and other key parameters (lead time, ROP, etc.), reducing assurance and control for the material team. As a result, there is a higher risk of mismatches between actual stock and agreed quantities, slower response to demand fluctuations, and recurring issues such as supply failures, unreliable material commitments, late deliveries, and heavy manual effort in data compilation.

Search & Knowledge Retrieval, Recommendation Systems / Personalization, Other: Flexible API, Document Intelligence (data extraction from PDFs, forms, contracts), Conversational AI / Chatbots, Predictive Analytics / Forecasting, Generative AI (text, image, video, code generation)
Expected Outcomes:
Success metrics
Key data is available (max stock, ParagonCorp ROP, POs, supplier capacity) but scattered across multiple platforms, not real-time, and often delayed by up to a month.
Integration:
Deployment:
Infrastructure:

Prototype Setup: October - November 2026 (1–2 ERP suppliers + 1 non-ERP supplier). Pilot Launch: December 2026 (3 RM suppliers + 3 PM suppliers with ERP, 1 RM & 1 PM supplier without ERP). Rollout Goal: Q1/Q2 2026 → full-scale implementation with SAP–supplier platform integration.
